SEVEN APPLY FOR COMMISSIONS
Members of Hopkins Corps Send in
Applications to Government--If War
Is Declared, Corps May Drill
Two Hours Daily.

A number of officers of the Reserve Officers' Training Corps of
Hopkins have sent in their applications for commissions as second
lieutenants in the Officers' Reserve
Corps. They are Captains Darley, Thompson and Chesley and
Lieutenants Baxley and Baker.
First Sergeant Friedlander, Lieutenant Elliott's assistant, is also
hoping that his application for a
captaincy in that corps will be
accepted, and Harry L. Straus,
the captain of the track team, is
awaiting news as to the acceptance of his request for a second
lieutenancy. Major Linton was
granted a second lieutenancy in
the Officers' Reserve Corps some
time ago. Not a few officers are
eagerly awaiting their twentyfirst birthday, at which time they
expect to apply.
On last Thursday and Friday
nights, Lieutenant Elliott, who is
now rapidly recuperating from
the effects of his collision with an
automobile last Tuesday night
while on his way to deliver the
weekly evening lecture in military
science, conducted examinations
for admittance into the Officers'
Reserve Corps. Quite a number
of civilians took the examination,
but the results are as yet unknown. There are three more lectures before the completion of the
preparatory course for flip examinations.
During the past week, Lieutenant Elliott has been conferring
with the president and the members of the Academic Advisory
Council about the plans that will
be adopted should war be declared.
It has been decided that in that
event drills will be held every (lay,
except Sunday,from 4 to 6 o'clock
in the afternoon. All conflicting
laboratories and classes will,
therefore, be suspended and all interest will be centered on making
the drills as efficient and instructive as possible.
Lieutenant Elliott is now giving
the officers a chance to display the
knowledge they have gained in
sighting and attacking an enemy.
Members of the corps say that
this is not as easy as it sounds,
because the enemy comprises usually only six privates of the corps,
whose uniforms blend so perfectly
with the underbrush that they
are practically invisible at several
hundred yards. When the one
hundred and seventy rifles arrive,
these practice encounters will be
made more realistic.

'VARSITY READY FOR ALUMNI
"Tommy" Troxell to Head Veterans in
Saturday's Contest--New Men Will
Probably Be Tried Out
During the Game.

The 1917 lacrosse season will
open this Saturday with the game
between the 'Varsity hnd the
alumni at Homewood. Since the
game this year will be part of
the Alumni Day program, and
since the date of the game falls
so near the Easter holidays, it is
expected that an unusually large
number of old players will be on
hand.
"Tommy" Troxell, captain of
the 1915 'Varsity, has been appointed leader of the "vets," and
has already had quite a number
out practicing. More are expected out every day, and the alumni
should present its usual strong
aggregation when the whistle
blows on Saturday. Among the
old stars who are expected back
are Pitts Raleigh, Walter Blanck,
Julian Sears and Frankie Lamotte, as well as Alan Voshell,
Prevost Boyce and Arthur Knipp,
of last season's! team. Reaney
Wolfe, Gerhardt a n d "Bill"
Schmeisser and Johnny Huck, the
squad's coaches, will probably
also try to show the boys how it
should be done.
Several of this year's freshmen
have shown considerable promise
since outdoor work began, and
will probably be given an opportunity to display their abilities at
some time during the game.
Among the best of these are
"Shorty" Stuart, Howard Knipp
and "Sam" Silverstein, all candidates for the home positions and
"Tubby" Turner and Marion Defandorf, who have shown up well
on the defense in the practice
scrimmages.
As a whole, the team looks unusually good this year, and, despite the had weather, which has
come almost without fail on
Wednesdays and Saturdays (the
two big practice days), is very
well developed for this time of
the season. This, of course, has
in a large measure been brought
about by the fact that so many
of the men had already had valuable experience in the positions
in which they were tried by the
coaches.
A very attractive schedule is
being arranged for the second
team by S. I. Clark, assistant
manager of the 'Varsity. A game
has already been arranged with the
Swarthmore Athletic Club, to be
played in Baltimore on May 5,
the day on which the first team
goes to Philadelphia to play the
University of Pennsylvania. Other
games, including a trip, are being
planned, and the lacrosse management has asked it to be announced that it is not too late for
anybody who knows anything at
all about the game to come out for
the team.

HOPKINS POLITY CLUB FOUNDED
Group of Undergraduates to Discuss
Present International Problems-8
Charter Members—Burbage '19,
President -Meeting April 2.

Realizing the necessity of a
more thorough knowledge of international problems among the
University students in the future,
and the present obligation for the
intelligent study of such problems brought home by the war, a
group of undergraduates met on
the night of March 19 at the Hopkins Club, and there organized the
International Polity Club of
Johns Hopkins University.
Those present at the meeting—
D. W. Burbage, M. B. Carroll, G.
U. Carneal, R. Duncan, H. C. Evans, A. A. Hamburger, J. G. Rouse
and T. H. Spiers—will compose
the charter members of the club.
Future membership will be admitted only by the vote of these members. D. W. Burbage and A. A.
Hamburger were unanimously
chosen president and secretary,
respectively. The executive committee, consisting of H. C. Evans
(chairman), M. B. Carroll and .T.
G. Rouse, will have as its duties
the drafting of a constitution and
the management of all affairs
tending. toward the welfare and
interest of the club.
At each meeting, held once
every three weeks, several members will present in detail various
phases of topics bearing directly
on present questions of international interest. Then the discussion will be thrown open for free
and informal debate. The club
hopes quite frequently to secure
authoritative speakers on subjects
of current interest. At such occasions the public will be invited.
The policy of the organization

will be to avoid a partisan attitude on any topic. It will be entirely distinct from any propaganda of anti-preparedness and
sentimental pacifism. The club
does not represent any such movement, but is rather designed as a
means of acquainting college men
with the broader point of view
from which both war and peace are
beginning to be regarded, and as
a method of familiarizing the student with current international
problems.

Experiments Being Carried on by Dr.
Watson'to Determine Appearance
of Emotions and Instincts
in Babies.

Prof. John Watson, of the psychology department of the Johns
Hopkins University, has recently
been conducting experiments on
infants in the maternity ward at
the Hopkins Hospital. No thorough scientific work has ever
been done in trying to determine
the actions of emotions and instincts in babies, and the results
of Dr. Watson's experiments may
startle the psychological world.
The actual work is being carried
on in the psychological laboratory
.in the Phipps Clinic, where about
forty babies a month are subjected to the experiments.
The first experiments are to discover the earliest appearance of
emotions and also the situations
which bring out emotions. It is
hoped that this study will lead to
the development of methods by
which it will be possible to change
and break up wrong emotional attachments and to regulate certain
glands of the body that depend
upon these attachments.
Tests are also being made to determine the time of the appearance of the earliest instincts, as
a basis for getting an idea as to
the vocation for which the individual would best be fitted. A record of the ages at which various
instincts appear and at which different movements, such as co-ordinating eye and hand movements,
appear, it is hoped will give some
light on whether the infants have
normal brains. If the psychologists can discover by this means
whether an infant has a normal
or a backward brain, steps could
be taken so as to develop the child
along lines that would improve his
condition.
Left and right handedness is being studied, in order to find out
whether it is an instinct or merely the result of an accident or of
habit. In addition, every involuntary motion of the baby from the
time of birth is recorded.
It has been noted that an infant, if allowed to grasp a small
stick, will involuntarily draw himself up and hang suspended from
a few seconds to a minute. This
grasping reflex continues for about
the first four months in the normal child.
Great care has been exercised
in the handling and testing of the
infants. One accident has resulted and no ill health has developed
in any of the babies tested.

Dr. Ussher, of the American Hospital in
Van, Tells of Armenian Massacres
and of His Own Thrilling Experiences in Turkey.

Over 30 Men on Squad—Pitching De
partment Showing up Especially
Well--Many New Players
Out for Team.

Vivid descriptions of the horrible massacres of Christians by
the Turks And their insults to the
American flag colored the talk of
Dr. Ussher at the student massmeeting last Wednesday. In a
most graphic and thrilling manner the physician-in-chief of the
American hospital in Van, Turkey, narrated his experiences
among the Turkish atrocities in
the Lake Van region up to the
time when, unconscious from typhus fever, he was carried, slung
on a litter between two mules, to
a place of safety.
After a brief survey of how the
Turks drove the Armenians in the
Van region in flocks to be mustered into service and burned the
houses of the deserters, and how
they rescinded all the rights of
foreigners, except, to some extent,
of Americans, he portrayed the
attempt of the governor-general
of Van to requisition the drug
supplies of the hospital. When
Dr. Ussher refused to accede, a
captain and several policemen
broke into the hospital and demanded a barrel of epsom salts,
which they endeavored to remove
from the cellar.
Realizing that it was up to him
to defend American rights, Dr.
Ussher flatly refused to yield to
the mandates of the captain.
When eight policemen attempted
to remove him from the trap-door
leading to the cellar, Rev. E. A.
Yarrow, a missionary at Van,
stepped to his side, and after a
brisk encounter the police retreated. At this moment the Russian
consul appeared, -ordered the
Turks away, and next day compelled the governor-general to
apologize to Dr. Ussher.
A thrilling description was then
given by Dr. Ussher of the victorious 28-day fight of the Armenians
with the Turks, during which the
hospital buildings were perforated with cannon and rifle balls, the
Red Cross flag was shot down and
the American flag was riddled
bulets until it fell. Before the
battle, Dr. Ussher told the governor that he must not permit his
soldiers to fire on American prop• erty. In spite of this, the governor ordered the guns trained on
the hospital. All the inmates of
the hospital miraculously escaped,
however, with the exception of a
little girl.. "One shell," Dr. Usslier remarked, "was hurled into
a room containing 45 people, but
it burst harmlessly in a barrel of
water."

Members of Hopkins Corps Send in
Applications to Government--If War
Is Declared, Corps May Drill
Two Hours Daily.

A number of officers of the Reserve Officers' Training Corps of
Hopkins have sent in their applications for commissions as second
lieutenants in the Officers' Reserve
Corps. They are Captains Darley, Thompson and Chesley and
Lieutenants Baxley and Baker.
First Sergeant Friedlander, Lieutenant Elliott's assistant, is also
hoping that his application for a
captaincy in that corps will be
accepted, and Harry L. Straus,
the captain of the track team, is
awaiting news as to the acceptance of his request for a second
lieutenancy. Major Linton was
granted a second lieutenancy in
the Officers' Reserve Corps some
time ago. Not a few officers are
eagerly awaiting their twentyfirst birthday, at which time they
expect to apply.
On last Thursday and Friday
nights, Lieutenant Elliott, who is
now rapidly recuperating from
the effects of his collision with an
automobile last Tuesday night
while on his way to deliver the
weekly evening lecture in military
science, conducted examinations
for admittance into the Officers'
Reserve Corps. Quite a number
of civilians took the examination,
but the results are as yet unknown. There are three more lectures before the completion of the
preparatory course for flip examinations.
During the past week, Lieutenant Elliott has been conferring
with the president and the members of the Academic Advisory
Council about the plans that will
be adopted should war be declared.
It has been decided that in that
event drills will be held every (lay,
except Sunday,from 4 to 6 o'clock
in the afternoon. All conflicting
laboratories and classes will,
therefore, be suspended and all interest will be centered on making
the drills as efficient and instructive as possible.
Lieutenant Elliott is now giving
the officers a chance to display the
knowledge they have gained in
sighting and attacking an enemy.
Members of the corps say that
this is not as easy as it sounds,
because the enemy comprises usually only six privates of the corps,
whose uniforms blend so perfectly
with the underbrush that they
are practically invisible at several
hundred yards. When the one
hundred and seventy rifles arrive,
these practice encounters will be
made more realistic.

Probably Be Tried Out

The 1917 lacrosse season will
open this Saturday with the game
between the 'Varsity hnd the
alumni at Homewood. Since the
game this year will be part of
the Alumni Day program, and
since the date of the game falls
so near the Easter holidays, it is
expected that an unusually large
number of old players will be on
hand.
"Tommy" Troxell, captain of
the 1915 'Varsity, has been appointed leader of the "vets," and
has already had quite a number
out practicing. More are expected out every day, and the alumni
should present its usual strong
aggregation when the whistle
blows on Saturday. Among the
old stars who are expected back
are Pitts Raleigh, Walter Blanck,
Julian Sears and Frankie Lamotte, as well as Alan Voshell,
Prevost Boyce and Arthur Knipp,
of last season's! team. Reaney
Wolfe, Gerhardt a n d "Bill"
Schmeisser and Johnny Huck, the
squad's coaches, will probably
also try to show the boys how it
should be done.
Several of this year's freshmen
have shown considerable promise
since outdoor work began, and
will probably be given an opportunity to display their abilities at
some time during the game.
Among the best of these are
"Shorty" Stuart, Howard Knipp
and "Sam" Silverstein, all candidates for the home positions and
"Tubby" Turner and Marion Defandorf, who have shown up well
on the defense in the practice
scrimmages.
As a whole, the team looks unusually good this year, and, despite the had weather, which has
come almost without fail on
Wednesdays and Saturdays (the
two big practice days), is very
well developed for this time of
the season. This, of course, has
in a large measure been brought
about by the fact that so many
of the men had already had valuable experience in the positions
in which they were tried by the
coaches.

being arranged for the second

all about the game to come out for

Group of Undergraduates to Discuss
Present International Problems-8
Charter Members—Burbage '19,
President -Meeting April 2.

Realizing the necessity of a
more thorough knowledge of international problems among the
University students in the future,
and the present obligation for the
intelligent study of such problems brought home by the war, a
group of undergraduates met on
the night of March 19 at the Hopkins Club, and there organized the
International Polity Club of
Johns Hopkins University.
Those present at the meeting—
D. W. Burbage, M. B. Carroll, G.
U. Carneal, R. Duncan, H. C. Evans, A. A. Hamburger, J. G. Rouse
and T. H. Spiers—will compose
the charter members of the club.
Future membership will be admitted only by the vote of these members. D. W. Burbage and A. A.
Hamburger were unanimously
chosen president and secretary,
respectively. The executive committee, consisting of H. C. Evans
(chairman), M. B. Carroll and .T.
G. Rouse, will have as its duties
the drafting of a constitution and
the management of all affairs
tending. toward the welfare and
interest of the club.
At each meeting, held once
every three weeks, several members will present in detail various
phases of topics bearing directly
on present questions of international interest. Then the discussion will be thrown open for free
and informal debate. The club
hopes quite frequently to secure
authoritative speakers on subjects
of current interest. At such occasions the public will be invited.
The policy of the organization

will be to avoid a partisan attitude on any topic. It will be entirely distinct from any propaganda of anti-preparedness and
sentimental pacifism. The club
does not represent any such movement, but is rather designed as a
means of acquainting college men
with the broader point of view
from which both war and peace are
beginning to be regarded, and as
a method of familiarizing the student with current international
problems.

Prof. John Watson, of the psychology department of the Johns

been done in trying to determine

startle the psychological world.
The actual work is being carried

forty babies a month are subjected to the experiments.
The first experiments are to discover the earliest appearance of
emotions and also the situations
which bring out emotions. It is
hoped that this study will lead to

glands of the body that depend

light on whether the infants have

condition.

stick, will involuntarily draw himself up and hang suspended from
a few seconds to a minute. This

ultimate supremacy of reason. It
is fundamentally wrong for social

University affairs. If fraternities
are a necessary evil, let them exist at night, during week-ends, off

Dr. Ussher, of the American Hospital in
Van, Tells of Armenian Massacres
and of His Own Thrilling Experiences in Turkey.

Vivid descriptions of the horrible massacres of Christians by
the Turks And their insults to the
American flag colored the talk of
Dr. Ussher at the student massmeeting last Wednesday. In a
most graphic and thrilling manner the physician-in-chief of the
American hospital in Van, Turkey, narrated his experiences
among the Turkish atrocities in
the Lake Van region up to the
time when, unconscious from typhus fever, he was carried, slung
on a litter between two mules, to
a place of safety.
After a brief survey of how the
Turks drove the Armenians in the
Van region in flocks to be mustered into service and burned the
houses of the deserters, and how
they rescinded all the rights of
foreigners, except, to some extent,
of Americans, he portrayed the
attempt of the governor-general
of Van to requisition the drug
supplies of the hospital. When
Dr. Ussher refused to accede, a
captain and several policemen
broke into the hospital and demanded a barrel of epsom salts,
which they endeavored to remove
from the cellar.
Realizing that it was up to him
to defend American rights, Dr.
Ussher flatly refused to yield to
the mandates of the captain.
When eight policemen attempted
to remove him from the trap-door
leading to the cellar, Rev. E. A.
Yarrow, a missionary at Van,
stepped to his side, and after a
brisk encounter the police retreated. At this moment the Russian
consul appeared, -ordered the
Turks away, and next day compelled the governor-general to
apologize to Dr. Ussher.
A thrilling description was then
given by Dr. Ussher of the victorious 28-day fight of the Armenians
with the Turks, during which the
hospital buildings were perforated with cannon and rifle balls, the
Red Cross flag was shot down and
the American flag was riddled
bulets until it fell. Before the
battle, Dr. Ussher told the governor that he must not permit his
soldiers to fire on American prop• erty. In spite of this, the governor ordered the guns trained on
the hospital. All the inmates of
the hospital miraculously escaped,
however, with the exception of a
little girl.. "One shell," Dr. Usslier remarked, "was hurled into
a room containing 45 people, but
it burst harmlessly in a barrel of
water."
